Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the fact that Larry Silverstein collected double the value of the insurance on the grounds of two attacks.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that Silverstein's decision to purchase terrorism insurance just before 9/11 was not a coincidence and that he must have known in advance about the terrorist attacks.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support to conclusively prove that Silverstein intentionally bought terrorism insurance due to foreknowledge of the attacks.
Exist alternative explanation: The expert suggests that Silverstein's decision to purchase terrorism insurance may not have been solely his own, as he was part of a consortium of investors and lenders who had a say in the insurance coverage.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the World Trade Center had some form of terrorism insurance before Silverstein took over, as implied by the expert's statement.
Falters at times: The claim falters by using scare quotes around the word "fortuitous" to imply that Silverstein's decision was not a coincidence, which may be misleading.
Understate: The claim may understate the complexity of the insurance coverage and the involvement of other entities in determining the coverage amount.
